articles.headline: U.S. Report Finds Errors in Afghan Airstrikes
articles.snippet: U.S. personnel made major errors in carrying out airstrikes that killed dozens of Afghan civilians, a military investigation has concluded.
articles.abstract: U.S. personnel made major errors in carrying out airstrikes that killed dozens of Afghan civilians, a military investigation has concluded.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A military investigation has concluded that American personnel made significant errors in carrying out some of the airstrikes in western Afghanistan on May 4 that killed dozens of Afghan civilians, according to a senior American military official.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: New-Vehicle Sales Reach a 2009 High
articles.snippet: New-vehicle sales in the U.S. climbed to their highest levels of the year in May, but demand for vehicles is still below the level automakers need to make a profit.
articles.abstract: New-vehicle sales in the U.S. climbed to their highest levels of the year in May, but demand for vehicles is still below the level automakers need to make a profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  New-vehicle sales in the United States climbed to their highest levels of the year in May, despite rising gas prices and the bankruptcies of General Motors and Chrysler. But demand is still below the levels that most automakers need to be profitable.

articles.headline: Health Insurers Balk at Some Changes
articles.snippet: The insurance industry says it backs a health care overhaul, but it has made no promises regarding the small-employer segment of the market.
articles.abstract: The insurance industry says it backs a health care overhaul, but it has made no promises regarding the small-employer segment of the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The insurance industry says it wholeheartedly embraces a health care overhaul, promising Congress and the president that it will make it much easier for individuals to buy insurance on their own.

articles.headline: Australia, Nourishing China’s Economic Engine, Questions Ties
articles.snippet: Chinese investments in Australian mining have tapped queasiness in Australia over China’s rising influence.
articles.abstract: Chinese investments in Australian mining have tapped queasiness in Australia over China’s rising influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia  If outlanders tend to associate Australia with kangaroos, broad-brim leather hats and an opera house, many Australians are different. They think of iron ore and bauxite, copper and coal, nickel, gold and uranium, a trove of mineral riches that is their nation’s birthright and the bedrock of its prosperity.

articles.headline: Investing in Lawsuits, for a Share of the Awards
articles.snippet: Investors are helping companies avoid some of litigation’s costs in exchange for part of any money paid out.
articles.abstract: Investors are helping companies avoid some of litigation’s costs in exchange for part of any money paid out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard W. Fields says he has come up with a win-win financial strategy for the downturn. He is investing in lawsuits.

articles.headline: India Feels Less Vulnerable as Outsourcing Presses On
articles.snippet: The pressure on companies, and even governments, to reduce costs means that many outsourcing businesses are booming.
articles.abstract: The pressure on companies, and even governments, to reduce costs means that many outsourcing businesses are booming.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOIDA, India — The global downturn has slowed the rapid growth in India’s outsourcing business, but only slowed it. In fact — because of the pressure on companies, and even governments, to reduce costs — many outsourcing businesses are booming. And a mood that was deeply uncertain just six months ago has turned much more optimistic.

articles.headline: Promised Help Is Elusive for Some Homeowners
articles.snippet: Millions of homeowners appear to qualify for mortgage assistance from the government but aren’t getting help.
articles.abstract: Millions of homeowners appear to qualify for mortgage assistance from the government but aren’t getting help.
articles.lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz.  She had seen the advertisements for the new government program offering relief. She had heard President Obama promise that help was on the way for homeowners like her, people who had lost jobs and could no longer make their mortgage payments.

articles.headline: Even Under a Cloud, G.M. Is Predicting Sunshine
articles.snippet: The carmaker, which has lost significant market share over the last three decades, projects in its bankruptcy filing that the slide will taper off.
articles.abstract: The carmaker, which has lost significant market share over the last three decades, projects in its bankruptcy filing that the slide will taper off.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors has been hemorrhaging customers for decades. For the last 30 years, it has been losing almost one percentage point of market share every year. It sold 45 percent of the new vehicles in this country in 1980, 35 percent in 1990, 28 percent in 2000 and 19 percent so far this year.

articles.headline: Detroit’s Woes Wound an Army of Suppliers
articles.snippet: Auto suppliers, which employ more workers than the car companies themselves, find their fortunes directly tied, for better or worse, to the automakers.
articles.abstract: Auto suppliers, which employ more workers than the car companies themselves, find their fortunes directly tied, for better or worse, to the automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nine years, the Strong brothers, Mark and Tim, made tools in their machine shop to maintain the giant presses that stamped steel sheets into fenders and hoods at a nearby General Motors factory in Lansing, Mich.
